Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned a lot of calculus in multiple dimensions.

Through this course, I grew my knowledge in all things of higher degrees in calculus with incredible efficiency. It was perhaps the class that both stretched me the most conceptually and taught me the most this semester. I learned skills in problem-solving, note-taking, and exam taking, that will certainly help me over the course of the next few years.
I have learned multivariable calculus
Multivariable calculus. 3D stuff.
I learned an essential background knowledge in multivariable calculus.
I learned all of the concepts involving the course. I also really learned how to study for math in an effective way.
I learned the basics of calculus in multiple dimensions.
I developed the basic skills related to multivariable calculus.
I learned all about calculus and my math skills developed immensely.
Everything - this class was the  GOAT. I learned all about vectors, vector fields, and all that spicy shit.

I gained significant skills related to visual omg 3D objects and how to calculate it. I also improved my abilities on how to approach a problem and how to chose the pathways I have available to solve it.
I developed a thorough understanding of vector calculus and much greater appreciation for math.
This course laid excellent foundations for multivariable calculus. You more or less can expect to expand upon what you know about integrals and derivatives to higher dimensions than in 112 and 115.

-problem solving skills
-independent thinking
I think I developed a cool understanding of space. I can understand a lot of the equations I used in Physics this semester much more clearly.
I learned the basics of multivariable calculus, including line and flux integrals and how to work in a three d coordinate system.
I developed a very thorough understanding of the classic multivariable concepts, and had a greater understand of what each concept meant geometrically and algebraically.

I was able to think in terms of 3D figures, envisioning nonexistent figures in my mind. I was also able to think creatively within the mathematical world figuring out different approaches to very interesting problems.
Course was pretty good. It would be nice if we could move a little slower.

This course, and especially the section I was in, covers some very difficult material. I have no complaints about the way that we moved through the concepts and think that overall it was very well executed. Sometimes we would attempt in-class problems that were beyond our grasp of the material which would be a waste of about 10 minutes until we actually learned how to do them, but that was rare.
Eh, it's a pretty standard intro math class I guess. Exams could be graded more nicely.
The strength of the class was my instructor, Sudesh. I cannot thank him enough. He was available all of the time and committed to helping us understand all concepts.
For the entire semester there werent enough chairs for the number of kids in my class. I sat on the floor multiple times.
It's a great course. Having problem sets due the same day as midterm exams was tough, but it helped me prepare for the test.
Handouts were extremely helpful. The amount of office hours was very helpful. Smaller homeworks due each class (rather than weekly problem sets) would be more beneficial to learning the material.
The teachers vary. My teacher was amazing but I heard that some of the others were not as good.
It is a really fun course, although hard. Visualizing and quantifying 3D objects was something really far from what I though I could do and when I finally learned it I felt accomplished

The exams are worth  90 percent of your grade (40 midterm, 50 final) which is horrible and scary. Review sessions were not very helpful, except the ones by Sudesh Kalyanswamy. Sudesh is the only thing that made MATH120 bearable (even enjoyable).

This was a great math course, and it had many strengths. Most of all, it was extremely well-organized by Sudesh. The curriculum was engaging, and there was plenty of help outside of class (office hours) available to students. In addition, before each exam, instructors would also hold numerous review sessions and Sudesh would post plenty of practice exam and practice problems, both of which really helped with exam preparation. Overall, it was an excellent course.

The approach of various TF's could be standardized, with the resources of one TF made available to all course students. I felt very fortunate to have a great TF who created practice problems with every lecture, but I imagine this course could become frustrating if your TF didn't care as much as mine did.

-very well organised 
-sudesh taught the course well
-could be more in depth about visualisations

I hated how monotonous the problem sets were. They always felt like a chore, rather than an aid to learning like problem sets in other classes. I understand that practice is necessary, but I felt like the practice problems did not adequately prepare me to take the tests. I think if I only did the exam practice problems instead of any homework at all, I would be more prepared to do well on exams. 
Many times I felt like I understood the material, but actually the practice problems I were doing were not varied enough to completely cover the variety on the tests. There is a lot of memorization involved to even start doing problems.
I realize that the peer tutor system was in place, but I never felt the need to visit them instead of my professor (Sudesh.) 
The homework is supposed to be weighted much less so you can feel comfortable using them for practice, but most people work with friends until they get all correct answers anyway, even if they don't understand the material as well. 
The exams are extremely high stake. If you do poorly on any single test, it is very difficult to recover because the material just keeps ramping up. There is partial credit, but if you misread a question or misunderstand the setup to one full problem (out of the 6-7 on the test) it will ruin you. I'd rather have more tests on more material to test complete understanding instead of the narrow focus on a few things it is now.
I thought the course was taught very well and see no ways to really improve it.

The course moves at a very fast pace, and I think the content is very difficult. I noticed that each instructor varies widely in their teaching styles, and although they are knowledgeable, they may not be the best instructors. I think the instructors for these courses could be more standardized to improve the student's ability to learn.

The amount of worksheets and extra practice problems was incredibly helpful. My professor would print out notes that would help students focus on the concepts and process of the problem instead of writing it down.

No weaknesses, particularly with my professor.
Yes, good class if you want to learn more math.
For any student interested in mathematics, this course is a necessity. Any student outside of that world, however, I would not encourage to take it.
I mean you probably need it, though it's not as bad as people say it is.
I would highly recommend this course, especially when taught by Sudesh. This course is a prerequisite for many majors and the knowledge you'll gain is essential.
Yes. I learned so much in this class and it was enjoyable to take part in.
I would recommend Sudesh
Yes
Yes I would recommend this course to another student. It contained a lot of fascinating material. Much better than Math 115.
Yes, I loved the course as a whole and I feel the skills are very important.
Absolutely, and make sure you take it with Sudesh, the ultra GOAT. I have literally never had a better teacher than Sudesh in any class in my entire life.
Yes, and take it with Sudesh. Best professor

Yes!! Absolutely take it if Sudesh is course coordinator or teaching. I initially dreaded taking this course after hearing bad reviews, but Sudesh's lectures are life changing and will make you truly appreciate how beautiful and wonderful math can be. I've always disliked math and never wanted to take more than one math course in college, but this course has changed my mind. Sudesh is really organized and provides plenty of practice problems (along with super helpful lecture notes) for each lecture, which is really useful and helpful for exam preparation. Overall, an excellent course, and if you get the chance to take it with Sudesh, absolutely take it!!!
If you have to take it, it's a survivable course. Do your best to take the class with Sudesh -- he is by far the most popular TF for good reason.
Yes, I think that It enforces useful skills and the knowledge gained is very applicable to real life problems, although this is easier to see when taking physics alongside

No. If you don't have to take this class as a prerequisite, there is no reason to take this class. From my knowledge, the class's difficulty depends heavily on the professor you get, and that is a risky gamble. It is very possible to ace the class if you do all of the given material, but the sheer monotony of it makes it feel un-worthwhile. If you have no intrinsic reason to take this class, avoid it. 

The exams are extremely high stake. If you do poorly on any single test, it is very difficult to recover because the material just keeps ramping up. If you do decide to take this class, start strong and don't get overconfident on the first few weeks of material. It only gets harder and you have to maintain your level of understanding, or else you will fall behind.
The grading scale is too harsh for this class for me to recommend this course to another student. I would recommend it if it was taken Credit/D/Fail, but it is still incredibly challenging.
Yes, if you want/need multi-variable calculus knowledge further on in college.

Of course. This course is very well organized and has very interesting topics. All the teachers for this course are willing to help you even if you are not in their class. It forces you to think very critically yet creatively, making it rather fun.
